text.title: part4_Wikinews interviews Australian Paralympic wheelchair basketballer Shelley Chaplin

p.s: Yeah , well our biggest strength was our defence , so if we can play the defence , we can .
The defence was where you won those games .
You blocked them off .

Particularly
Mexico
, they could n't ... Canada was even better .
You kept on forcing turnovers , forcing timeouts .
That was the defensive game , was the way you won it .
Absolutely .
But Germany had a good defensive game as well .
It must have been good , playing on your birthday .
It was really cool .
The whole team , the whole Australian Paralympic team wished me happy birthday , the whole crowd sang me happy birthday and this sort of stuff .
It was pretty special , but once you get into it , it 's just another game .
I know all the people were talking about the fact that it was my birthday , but it did n't [ get to me ] .
It was fun .
It was fun .
Not a bad place to have your birthday .
So how do you compare London with Beijing and Athens ?
Well , I think every games gets a little bit better anyway .
Like , Beijing was better than Athens and I think London was a lot better than Beijing again .

But I think the special thing about London is that it was
British
, and so they obviously support Australians ,
but
we were just athletes to them , I think .
Whereas in Beijing we were still disabled athletes .
But in London we were just athletes and they loved our sport and they understood our sport , which was really cool .
The crowds ... it was amazing .
We have a lot of statistics on the response to it .

Unfortunately , being in London I could n't see the
TV
coverage .

Back here the
ABC
did a fantastic job with us .
Everybody knows about the Paralympics .
Everybody saw something .
Apparently there was extra requests for the Gliders .
So more people wanted to see you .
People like basketball .
Basketball is very easy to relate to .
Team sports are good to watch .
But I think , like I was saying earlier , if you take away the wheelchair , there 's nothing to do with disabilities .
If an able bodied jumped into a wheelchair , it 's exactly the same as us .
Whereas an able bodied ca n't run against someone with blades .
You know ?
Yes .
So I think that 's why ; it 's very relatable , and obviously it 's fun to watch .
It seems be be getting bigger with each set of games .
Definitely .

I 've got figures from
Google
.
London is twice as big .
Yep .
Absolutely .
The Paralympic movement is exciting because we 're all amateur athletes , and we 're all doing it because we love the sport .

I think , during Beijing , I know in the Australian media they tried to get everyone to look away from our disabilities and look at us just as athletes , but I think in London they were like , here 's their disabilities , here 's what they are doing athletically , and combining the two , which made for amazing coverage , right ? Cause everyone understood our disabilities but our sport as well .
